input:
This is a database schema:

ActiveRecord::Schema[7.0].define(version: 2023_02_25_165825) do
  # These are extensions that must be enabled in order to support this database
  enable_extension plpgsql

  create_table articles, force: :cascade do |t|
    t.string title
    t.string ingress
    t.string text
    t.datetime created_at, null: false
    t.datetime updated_at, null: false
    t.integer user_id
  end

  create_table authors, force: :cascade do |t|
    t.string first_name
    t.string last_name
    t.datetime created_at, null: false
    t.datetime updated_at, null: false
  end

  create_table users, force: :cascade do |t|
    t.string username
    t.string email
    t.string password_digest
    t.datetime created_at, null: false
    t.datetime updated_at, null: false
  end
end  Can you tell me to what articles have a relation?
response: Based on the provided database schema, the "articles" table has a relation with the "users" table through the "user_id" column. This indicates that each article belongs to a user.

input: Can you tell me what coloumns users have?
response:
Based on the provided database schema, the "users" table has the following columns:

1. username: This column stores the username of the user.
2. email: This column stores the email address of the user.
3. password_digest: This column stores the hashed password of the user.
4. created_at: This column stores the timestamp indicating when the user was created.
5. updated_at: This column stores the timestamp indicating when the user was last updated.
